documentType: court filing with attached personal statement
summary: This document is a civil judgment from the U.S. District Court dismissing a case against Ghislaine Maxwell and Jeffrey Epstein for lack of subject-matter jurisdiction, dated November 19, 2020. Attached is a notice of appeal and a personal statement from an anonymous plaintiff alleging sexual assault by Maxwell and physical assault by Epstein in 2001, and claiming to possess evidence including royal items and DNA.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: Named as a defendant in a civil case. The attached personal statement alleges she sexually assaulted the plaintiff in London in 2001.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: Named as a defendant in a civil case. The attached personal statement alleges he physically assaulted the plaintiff, causing injuries.

persons.name: Louis L. Stanton
persons.context: Signed the civil judgment dismissing the case for lack of subject-matter jurisdiction.

persons.name: Colleen McMahon
persons.context: Named in the document, likely as the judge to whom the plaintiff's impact statement is addressed.

persons.name: Paul Burrel
persons.context: Mentioned by the plaintiff as the person from whose collection royal items were allegedly given as bribes for silence, connected to Princess Diana's missing items.

persons.name: Prince Andrew
persons.context: Alleged by the plaintiff to be the source, via Paul Burrel, of royal items given as bribes for silence.

persons.name: Queen Elizabeth II
persons.context: Mentioned by the plaintiff as having given permission for Paul Burrel to keep items for safekeeping.

persons.name: Princess Diana
persons.context: Mentioned in relation to missing items from her collection that were allegedly disposed of on the black market.

connections.description: Named together as defendants in the same civil lawsuit. The plaintiff alleges abuse by both.
Plaintiff alleges Maxwell said royal items used for bribery were from Prince Andrew via Paul Burrel.
Burrel is described as having a collection from Princess Diana's missing items.
Plaintiff alleges Maxwell sexually assaulted them in London in 2001.
Plaintiff alleges Epstein stabbed them in the hands, causing physical injury.

events.title: Alleged Assault in London
events.description: The plaintiff alleges they were sexually assaulted by Ghislaine Maxwell and physically assaulted (stabbed) by Jeffrey Epstein in London.

events.title: Civil Case Dismissal
events.description: U.S. District Judge Louis L. Stanton dismisses the civil case against Ghislaine Maxwell and Jeffrey Epstein for lack of subject-matter jurisdiction.

events.title: Notice of Appeal Filed
events.description: The plaintiff files a notice of appeal against the dismissal of their case, citing difficulties in providing evidence from the UK.

keyFacts: A civil case against Ghislaine Maxwell and Jeffrey Epstein was dismissed by a U.S. District Court on November 19, 2020, for lack of subject-matter jurisdiction.
An anonymous plaintiff alleges they were sexually assaulted by Ghislaine Maxwell and physically assaulted by Jeffrey Epstein in London in 2001.
The plaintiff claims to possess evidence including royal items allegedly given as bribes for silence, said to be from Prince Andrew via Paul Burrel's collection from Princess Diana's missing items.
The plaintiff claims to have a used condom containing Ghislaine Maxwell's DNA from the alleged 2001 assault.
The plaintiff describes severe and lasting physical and psychological injuries resulting from the alleged assaults, including a snapped penis, hip damage, and PTSD.
